p: Measurement of inflammation-related markers on serum samples from this cohort has been previously performed and reported [ 40]. Briefly, markers were measured on serum samples collected at baseline, using MesoScale Discovery (Rockville) electrochemiluminescent immunoassays, including the V-PLEX human pro-inflammatory panel 1 (IFN- γ, IL-1 β, IL-2, IL-4, IL-6, IL-8, IL-10, IL-12p70, IL-13, and TNF- α), and V-PLEX human CRP. All samples were run in duplicate and as per the manufacturer’s protocol [ 40] which yields the following values for the inflammatory markers considered in our analysis: Inter- assay % CVs for CRP: 7.2%; TNF-alpha: 7.4%; IL–6:6.8%; IL–10:7.9% and IFN-gamma: 8.2%. Intra-assay % CVs for CRP: 2.2%; TNF-alpha: 2.4%; IL–6:3.9%; IL–10:3.1% and IFN-gamma: 3.8%. Lower Limit of Detection for CRP: 1.33 pg/ml; TNF-alpha: 0.04 pg/ml; IL–6:0.06 pg/ml; IL–10:0.04 pg/ml and IFN-gamma: 0.37 pg/ml. From this existing data set, five pro-inflammatory markers (TNF-alpha, IFN-gamma, CRP, IL-6 and IL-10) were selected because they had the strongest loadings on the pro-inflammatory component scores in our previous principal component analysis (PCA) in this ICICLE-PD dataset [ 40]. In this study we sought to validate the findings of Williams-Gray et al. [ 40] but through the use of a smaller number of parameters combined into a simple composite score, which does not require a PCA-based approach.
